title.narrative: Academic performance of disadvantaged girls in Sierra Leone

description.narrative: Over the past decade the Government of Sierra Leone has undertaken steps to improve access to and quality of education. They have recently revised the structure of the system to extend secondary school and create a 3-6-3-4-4 system: 3 years of pre-school; 6 at primary; 3 at junior secondary school; 4 at senior secondary school and 4 at tertiary level. However, students’ performance in examinations remains one of the lowest in West Africa, in part due to the civil war and the resultant loss of a skilled labour force. A gender imbalance between girls and boys education has been identified both in terms of access and underperformance, especially access to STEM subjects (science, technology, engineering and maths) for girls, which is extremely low. This application will identify the barriers facing female students in studying STEM subjects at secondary school. It will look at the barriers facing girls entering junior secondary schools and moving from junior through to senior secondary schools. It also aims to provide a space to girls to voice their own views and engage the community in issues of girls’ education
